title: How was this ban worthy?
body:
"Hey there LewdTheLolis,

SanguineDogma here with the Player Support Team, and it'd be my pleasure to help you out today!

I know that you were just repeating the language that another player was using so that you could give everyone else in the game a heads-up on that bad behavior, but as I was looking through the rest of these chat logs, I found that this Permanent Ban was correctly placed for the use of Racial Slurs:

[9:06] [All] LewdTheLolis (Alistar): %%%%% got no power"

I do not understand how this counted as a racial slur. I am black and have lived in a black community all my life and banning over this normal slang makes no sense. This one time use is not transparent of the rules regarding language and at the  least would like riot to be consistent on what can be said.
One sentence with no flame should not give a perma ban when I have been reformed since my only other 14 day ban.

replies.body:
> I am black and have lived in a black community all my life and banning over this normal slang makes no sense.

You can use that term there because that's a culture where your meaning is understood and accepted. That's not the case here. Also, text is terrible for conveying tone, so the rules have to be stricter.

My message to my team was clearly understood when the guy told us he had a power outage. My tone was clear and riot would see that if they look at the game. Also, how would I know a commonly used word is offensive when riot isnt transparent about their own rules? I dont care that im banned but would like riot to understand this can never be looked at as "offensive"

> would like riot to understand this can never be looked at as "offensive"

That's an opinion you can have. Just know it isn't shared by the community or by Riot.
Exactly, we don't know what your skin color is either or (And I mean no offence) if you're just saying you're black to get off the hook even if you're not really black.

Are you playing League in a black community? No.

Would you talk like that at work? Depends on your industry, but likely not.

Your 14-day ban ended less than a month ago, which isn't much time to demonstrate reform.
How would one even play league in a 'black community'???

That's exactly my point. OP isn't playing League in a community like the one he grew up in, and he should have adjusted his speech accordingly, as one might do at a job, or when meeting new people, or in class, etc.

People have said it at a job, when meeting new people (because the term is relatively synonymous as 'bro' and 'homie' and is used most prominently as a greeting), and in every American classroom. Furthermore, this is an online video game and should be treated as such, not a corporate meeting. Permanently banning this man for using his words and denying him from using his culture is wrong.

First off, "denying him from using his culture" is comically overblowing what it means to call a friend the n-word, hard r or no.

More importantly, granting this right would infringe on others enjoyment of the game. Why isn't it acceptable to you that folks should treat others with respect? Using the n-word without knowing who you're talking to is objectively disrespectful.

It is very much subjective and saying it with an 'a' is no way disrespectful.

Also growing up in a mostly black community, saying the n-word is more common than saying every other greeting, and getting banned for that is clearly him getting punished for expressing his culture. 

No one would have a miserable time playing a game made for enjoyment after hearing the n-word anymore than you would be miserable after hearing someone call their friend '-ga' while walking down a street.

Possibly - but for every one person who uses it non-offensively, nine more would jump at the opportunity to use a very real racial slur with impunity. There needs to be a line in the sand somewhere and this is where Riot has chosen to draw it on this issue.

> [{quoted}](name=xxxoooxoxo,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=IbgoELgU,comment-id=0000000100000000,timestamp=2018-12-24T04:26:15.692+0000)
>
> and denying him from using his culture is wrong.

It isn't part of black culture it's part of ignorant fool culture. It has no place anywhere.

No one who is proud of their heritage uses it.

it wasnt hard r, used one time directed at no one and why would anyone talk in an online videogame like they do at work? that is incomparable. I get banning over actual racial slurs but this isnt one of them

It's not incomparable at all. You're assigned to work in a team with people you didn't know before. You don't know their backgrounds, values, senses of humor, etc., and neither do they know yours. Using racially charged language, hard r or no, is disrespectful in such a setting.

"hard r" isn't a thing.

If I say "sup" versus "What's up" it means the same damn thing, doesn't it?
In practice, one is harsher than the other, but that's only relevant in a few situations. Neither is appropriate in mixed company. Both would get you fired from your job.

People at my job say it all the time? its not a racial slur; hes literally using common language, and to discriminate a POC for using a word that is used as a form of affection and greeting is entirely unethical and outright wrong. disappointing to see Riot ignore this issue.

Genuinely curious to hear what your job is.

Beyond that, you're speaking as though the context of OP's use of the word is clear. It's not. The word is highly controversial. Here's from the Wikipedia entry for it:

>In practice, its use and meaning are heavily dependent on context.[1] Presently, the word %%%%% is used more liberally among younger members of all races and ethnicities in the United States.[2] In addition to African America, other ethnic groups have adopted the term as part of their vernacular.[3][4]

>There is conflicting popular opinion on whether there is any meaningful difference between %%%%% and %%%%%% as a spoken term.[5] Many people consider the terms to be equally pejorative, and the use of %%%%% both in and outside black communities remains controversial.[6] H. Lewis Smith, author of Bury that Sucka: A Scandalous Affair with the N-word, believes that "replacing the 'er' with an 'a' changes nothing other than the pronunciation"[7] and the African American Registry notes, "Brother (Brotha) and Sister (Sistah or Sista) are terms of endearment. %%%%%% was and still is a word of disrespect."[8] The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, a civil rights group, condemns use of both %%%%% and %%%%%%.[5]

>Some African-Americans only consider %%%%% offensive when used by people of other races,[5] seeing its use outside a defined social group as an unwelcome cultural appropriation. Used by blacks, the term may indicate "solidarity or affection",[9] similar to the usage of the words dude, homeboy, and bro. Others consider "%%%%%" non-offensive except when directed from a non-African-American towards an African-American. Yet others have derided this as hypocritical and harmful, enabling white racists to use the word and confusing the issue over %%%%%%.[3]

I'm not an idiot. I realize that there are uses for the word that are not intended to be racist. But I can't relate to the assumption that those uses would be clear during a game of League, or that somebody would honestly think that the questionable slang they're using in their specific neighborhood is somehow universal.

> [{quoted}](name=xxxoooxoxo,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=IbgoELgU,comment-id=00000000000100000000,timestamp=2018-12-24T04:12:58.149+0000)
>
> People at my job say it all the time? its not a racial slur; hes literally using common language, and to discriminate a POC for using a word that is used as a form of affection and greeting is entirely unethical and outright wrong. disappointing to see Riot ignore this issue.

Umm theyre clearly not ignoring the issue if they issued a punishment in relation to it. They just dont agree with your opinion on it. Disagreement does not mean they are ignoring it. They made a stance... a strong one that has consequences even. Seems like the opposite of ignoring something.

Oh, come on, dude, you know that's a horrible analogy.

"'Sup" and "What's up" mean the same thing. The only difference is connotation. The N word ending with -er and ending with -a generally mean two completely different things. The former is a term usually used for racist abuse, and the other is a term usually used by black people with a distinctly non-racist meaning.
I'm not black. May I say it?

> [{quoted}](name=rujitra,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=IbgoELgU,comment-id=000000000001,timestamp=2018-12-24T03:57:55.795+0000)
>
> "hard r" isn't a thing.
> 
> If I say "sup" versus "What's up" it means the same damn thing, doesn't it?

it does not mean anywhere near the same thing. how out of touch with the world are you even assume something so ignorant?

In fact, it is people like you who think they don't mean the same thing that are out of touch with the world.

Both words come from racism. Pure, and many times violent, racism.

The attempt of you and some others to "reclaim" the word by removing the "hard r" does not change the fact that for the large majority of society it is still an unacceptably racist term to use.
Only a small majority thinks its racist. Have you heard any modern music in the last 15 years? it is very very very much accepted and has formed pop-culture.

Pop culture isn't the _only_ culture, something that's important to remember. League culture has to support a great many perspectives and attitudes. Unfortunately, "no hard R being okay" can't be part of that.

I listen to music because I enjoy listening to it. For example, there's multiple songs that I listen to that contain the N word (either -er or -a), and the only reason I listen to them is because I love the tune, chorus, whatever. Simply listening to music with the "N word" does not mean people think it is acceptable.

Where the word comes from doesn't determine its current meaning, otherwise another word we're not allowed to say here would merely mean a bundle of sticks, and another one would refer to a British schoolboy acting as a servant to a senior student.

I know this is a sensitive topic for a lot of people.

 Unfortunately, according to Riot, using homophobic or racist terms is strictly zero tolerance and is never acceptable. That word is classified as a racist term to most companies and workplaces. 

Rules are rules, but I'm still sorry you caught a ban for this. Personally, I don't agree with it.

What's a better way to handle it? If the company is committed to cracking down on hate speech, subjective analysis of the use of slurs to situationally give leniency would just add much more confusion and inconsistency to the system.
Its not hate speech if the term is used as a greeting and wasn't directed at anyone.....

But with text anyone can interpret it in anyway. Just by being ambiguous like that someone is always going to assume the worse. This is the reason why this as well as other words are Zero Tolerance. If we let it slide way too many people will try and abuse the system by claiming they didn't mean it: "in this way or that way". Its best to just ban it all together because that will leave too much work for the staff as well as someone else put, confuse people as to what is/isn't acceptable.
Banning an African American for saying "-gga" is wrong. Obviously it is different if it were '-er', but it isn't and this is common tongue.

How in the hell do we figure out who gets to say what? How is this at all a workable solution?

Do League players get to opt-in to specific racial slurs based on their background? Cool, I deserve free usage of homophobic hate speech because I grew up in the South. Anything less than that is a violation of my culture.

People don't walk around calling people "f**" as a greeting, if it was commonly accepted then that is a different story; the workable solution is that -a is not bannable but -er is strictly prohibited.

> [{quoted}](name=Jo0o,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=IbgoELgU,comment-id=00010000,timestamp=2018-12-24T03:56:48.541+0000)
>
> What's a better way to handle it? If the company is committed to cracking down on hate speech, subjective analysis of the use of slurs to situationally give leniency would just add much more confusion and inconsistency to the system.

 That's the problem a lot of public figures and companies face. On one hand, the word has a disgusting history and shouldn't be socially acceptable, on the other hand, a lot of people use it as another way to greet each other or just slap it in everyday conversation. There's no denying that "-ga" is different from "-ger" but it's still a divisive word to a lot of people.

 That's why I said "Rules are rules" because even though I personally disagree with most companies ruling on it, I have to look at where they're coming from and follow their guidelines. I maybe could have worded it better when I said "Unfortunately" because it kind of seems like I'm ragging on Riot, my bad for that if it wasn't entirely clear.
Is it really that hard to just not use that word and be civilized.
Im saying the word had no racial or negative connotation when used in that sentence. It was used as affection and everyone understood
So then who reported you? Obviously someone didnt like it or understood that you werent using it in a negative way!

I was reported by an inting teammate (Yes he blatantly inted riot can view the game)and a teammate that was afk for 15 minutes, where my comment of him having no power was the issue to riot. They were queued and only reported me because i told them they were ruining the game for us, where he preceded to call me a %%%. They were upset with me and i get punished for not flaming or harassment
You have no idea who reported you.
watch the game and when the guy called me a homophobic slur you can easily deduct it was him as 2 other teammates defended me and the other team sympathized with me over an afk and inter...

Get over it, you broke the rule, now you got punished. 
If you're so tough and such a badass in your 'hood', then drop the whining and deal with it like a man....
Riot does not consider context, ever.
I'm black and i dont find that word offensive at all. I like letting people have and express their opinions regardless if it is "hate".
